articles.headline: Bribes Corrode Afghans’ Trust in Government
articles.snippet: The state built on the ruins of the Taliban regime now often seems to exist for little more than the enrichment of those who run it.
articles.abstract: The state built on the ruins of the Taliban regime now often seems to exist for little more than the enrichment of those who run it.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  When it comes to governing this violent, fractious land, everything, it seems, has its price.

articles.headline: As Recession Deepens, So Does Milk Surplus
articles.snippet: Dairy farmers have a dilemma: what to do with cows and a growing glut of milk as prices drop sharply.
articles.abstract: Dairy farmers have a dilemma: what to do with cows and a growing glut of milk as prices drop sharply.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOWLER, Calif.  The long economic boom, fueled by easy credit that allowed people to spend money they did not have, led to a huge oversupply of cars, houses and shopping malls, as recent months have made clear. Now, add one more item to the list: an oversupply of cows.

articles.headline: Madoff Investor’s Suicide Leaves Questions
articles.snippet: Relatives said Rene-Thierry Magon de la Villehuchet — who committed suicide in the wake of the Madoff scandal — felt personally responsible losing his clients’ money.
articles.abstract: Relatives said Rene-Thierry Magon de la Villehuchet — who committed suicide in the wake of the Madoff scandal — felt personally responsible losing his clients’ money.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the days after Bernard L. Madoff was arrested and accused of orchestrating a $50 billion Ponzi scheme, one of his investors  Rene-Thierry Magon de la Villehuchet  struggled with his role in the fraud.
articles.byline: By Alex Berenson and Matthew Saltmarsh

articles.headline: Economy Blunts Korea’s Appetite for Plastic Surgery
articles.snippet: An indicator of the economic doldrums in South Korea: Seoul’s obsession with plastic surgery is waning, and once-crowded clinics are closing.
articles.abstract: An indicator of the economic doldrums in South Korea: Seoul’s obsession with plastic surgery is waning, and once-crowded clinics are closing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL  A grim frugality has settled over this export powerhouse that once burst with optimism  and silicone.

articles.headline: Steel Industry, in Slump, Looks to Federal Stimulus
articles.snippet: The steel industry, a bellwether for the state of the nation’s economy, is looking to the government for a $1 trillion investment program over two years.
articles.abstract: The steel industry, a bellwether for the state of the nation’s economy, is looking to the government for a $1 trillion investment program over two years.
articles.lead_paragraph: The steel industry, having entered the recession in the best of health, is emerging as a leading indicator of what lies ahead. As steel production goes  and it is now in collapse  so will go the national economy.

articles.headline: Worldwide, a Bad Year Only Got Worse
articles.snippet: After a catastrophic year for global markets, analysts are cautioning investors not to expect the big rebound that usually follows a sharp downturn.
articles.abstract: After a catastrophic year for global markets, analysts are cautioning investors not to expect the big rebound that usually follows a sharp downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS  After a catastrophic year for global markets, dazed investors are emerging from their shelters to ask if 2009 will be any better. The consensus among professionals? Do not expect the big rebound that usually follows a sharp downturn.

articles.headline: Contradictions in China, and the Rise of a Billionaire Family
articles.snippet: The story of Liu Yongxing — a former factory worker who is now listed by Forbes as the wealthiest person in China — is a peek into the changes facing China.
articles.abstract: The story of Liu Yongxing — a former factory worker who is now listed by Forbes as the wealthiest person in China — is a peek into the changes facing China.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUJIA VILLAGE, China  In the 1950s, the Liu family of southwest China’s Sichuan Province was so short of food, they sent one of their youngest sons to be raised by another family.

articles.headline: Play Flute, Name a Tune (or Make a Call)
articles.snippet: Downloadable applications available for new cellphones can be fun, quirky and even useful.
articles.abstract: Downloadable applications available for new cellphones can be fun, quirky and even useful.
articles.lead_paragraph: So your cellphone has a brushed-metal shell, can flip and slide four ways and has more buttons than an airplane cockpit. Big deal.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Laura M. Holson

articles.headline: A Focus on Violence by Returning G.I.’s
articles.snippet: The Army is reviewing whether combat trauma played a role in killings by soldiers in Colorado.
articles.abstract: The Army is reviewing whether combat trauma played a role in killings by soldiers in Colorado.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT CARSON, Colo.  For the past several years, as this Army installation in the foothills of the Rocky Mountains became a busy way station for soldiers cycling in and out of Iraq, the number of servicemen implicated in violent crimes has raised alarm.
articles.byline: By Lizette Alvarez and Dan Frosch

articles.headline: Manufacturing Reports Show Depth of Global Downturn
articles.snippet: New reports from the world’s leading economies showed manufacturing continuing to slump amid the worst slowdown since the Great Depression.
articles.abstract: New reports from the world’s leading economies showed manufacturing continuing to slump amid the worst slowdown since the Great Depression.
articles.lead_paragraph: From Australia to Asia and Europe to the United States, the message on Wednesday in the latest economic reports was clear: manufacturing continued to slump amid the worst slowdown since the Great Depression.

articles.headline: Some Forecasters See a Fast Economic Recovery
articles.snippet: Many economists are heading into the new year declaring that the worst may soon be over. Others are pessimistic.
articles.abstract: Many economists are heading into the new year declaring that the worst may soon be over. Others are pessimistic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Economics as the dismal science? Not in some quarters.
